ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had readings, sometimes gave/received feedback through Panopto, worked on making films outside of class.
We had discussions on student's work using panopto.
asynchronous comments, sometimes
We met every week for a discussion section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about different aspects of filmmaking including the Frame, Lighting, Sound, Staging, Writing, Editing, One-shot, and refining. We also learned about equipment and the filmmaking process as well as looking closely at scenes from movies and how they incorporated these elements.

Professor Andrews did a stellar job of exposing us to all the fundamentals of film: lighting, staging, sound, framing, narrative, etc. By the end of this course you will be comfortable producing and editing the films you wish to create.
Even in a remote setting, I feel like I learned about aspects of filmmaking I didnt know before, and was able to refine some of the basic skills that I already have.
basic directing and writing knowledge as well as types of camera shots and storytelling tips
Filmmaking, how to direct, lighting, just all aspects of film pretty much.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I made many different styles of movies and got to experiment with filmmaking techniques. I received a lot of feedback from both the professor and the other students in the class. Received a filmmaking kit that was helpful.

Weaknesses: None.

The strengths of this course are Professor Andrews' expertise and ability to give critique to students that range in skill and level. Furthermore, the weekly assignments, though challenging, proved to force us to create and overcome the creative hump, something I think is ultimately the most valuable aspect of any class. The biggest weakness of the class was the readings. I found Geuens interesting but not very applicable in practice.
Prof. Andrews is a very attentive and passionate professor that cares about all of his students. He is willing to answer any questions you may have and is understanding of students' circumstances.

I don't know how it could be improved honestly. I thought this class was so enjoyable. The hardest part for me was finding people to act in my films because of covid but other than that, this course was very well taught. I even enjoyed the readings because it opened me up to interesting viewpoints of film attributes that helped me to learn more about film.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The teacher did a great job of transitioning the curriculum into a remote class.
I believe the ability to leave comments on canvas made the classmate critique more valuable.

I think having the virtual seminar worked because we were still able to have discussion and give notes on each others work. I think the method for notes that was settled on in the end where only half the class gives notes at a time worked the best.

Seminars worked well and we adjusted to find the best way of viewing student films in class. At times the workload could be a bit much in terms of cranking out student films each week with limited sets in the case of having to film with our quarantine pods, but I am not sure if there is any real solution to that in the case of adjusting to the pandemic.
All went smooth to be honest besides finding people to film with.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this was one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Yale and the fact that it was during the pandemic really shows how good both the class and Professor Andrews are.
Yes, this course is a great introduction to filming things with a purpose and exposing yourself to having to film things with a goal in mind.
I would only recommend this to someone interested in making short videos for the sake of making videos.

I would recommend this course to another student because it offers you the opportunity to make a lot of small projects and get feedback from them, so you can make a lot of mistakes and learn from them now, rather than in your future work.
If you are interested in learning about film and directing, then yes.
Yes. Especially with Prof. Jon Andrews.
